devdoc.details: Shows how Solidity 0.8.0+ handles integer overflow

getMoney().details: Function to get the current value

resetToMax().details: Function to reset the value to maximum

safeSetter().details: Function that demonstrates safe increment with require check

setter().details: Function that attempts to increment money by 1IMPORTANT: In production code, you should handle this case gracefully       or use SafeMath library for more control over error messages

uncheckedSetter().details: Function that demonstrates using unchecked block to allow overflow

returns._0: The new value after potential overflow

money.details: Unsigned 8-bit integer initialized to maximum value (255)

devdoc.title: Integer Overflow Demonstration

decrement().notice: Shows that Solidity also protects against underflowThis will revert if called when money = 0

money().notice: uint8 can hold values from 0 to 255 (2^8 - 1)We initialize to 255 to demonstrate overflow on increment

resetToMax().notice: Useful for testing the overflow behavior multiple times

safeSetter().notice: This shows how to manually prevent overflowEven though Solidity 0.8.0+ has built-in overflow protection,         explicit checks can provide better error messages

setter().notice: This will cause an overflow since money is already at max value (255)In Solidity 0.8.0+, this transaction will revert with:         "Arithmetic operation underflowed or overflowed outside of unchecked block"

uncheckedSetter().notice: Shows how to bypass Solidity's built-in overflow protectionWARNING: This is unsafe and should only be used when absolutely necessaryIn this case, money would wrap around to 0 (255 + 1 = 0)

userdoc.notice: This contract demonstrates the built-in overflow protection in modern SolidityIn versions before 0.8.0, this would silently wrap around (255 + 1 = 0)In 0.8.0+, this will revert with an overflow error
